docs.text: Introduction # This is a guide to help students to start doing research in computer science specifically in machine learning for computer vision. Neslihan Bayramgolu DIOS (Diagnostics of Osteoarthritis) group @ MIPT , University of Oulu I will be updating the page time to time. Please come again and check for the updates! IMPORTANT Please read carefully about M.Sc./Ph.D. study process at the the university: Information about M.Sc. studies: M.Sc. Information about Ph.D. studies: Ph.D. Content # Start Here - Start here. docs.text: Glossary osteophytes sclerosis tibial diarthodial bone spur cartilage subchondral bone femur distal Anterior lateral antero postero patella femoral condyle tibia Subchondral : layer of bone just below the cartilage in a joint Medial : in or toward the middle medial side of the knee is the side closest to the other knee whereas the lateral side of the knee is the outside of the knee. https://www.physio-pedia.com/Knee http://www.startradiology.com/internships/orthopedics/knee/x-knee/
docs.title: Glossary

docs.text: Assigned: 11 January 2019 Setup your environment as described here environment setup . Register and start learning the following course: https://www.coursera.org/learn/machine-learning Start learning Python
docs.title: Assignment 1

docs.text: Assigned: 08 February 2019 Check the following page and try to complete all of them but especially the 5 th assignment (related to segmentation) https://github.com/ytyytyyt/DIPcourse Segment individual cells in the following image: Consider preprocessing. Result does not need to be perfect. But try to segment them as good as possible. Try to segment touching cells. For the first visualization, use different color for each cell and paint inside the cell region. For the second visualization, plot only cell contours on the image. Cluster cells (with k-means) into three classes according to their sizes. Use a different color for each cluster for visualization. Email me the best results and a short description how did you approach the problem (also list the methods you used). Use scikit-image, scikit-learn libraries. UPDATE 10 March 2019 # Following links are good examples that use classical methods: https://www.kaggle.com/stkbailey/teaching-notebook-for-total-imaging-newbies https://www.kaggle.com/gaborvecsei/basic-pure-computer-vision-segmentation-lb-0-229 https://github.com/luispedro/python-image-tutorial/blob/master/Segmenting%20cell%20images%20(fluorescent%20microscopy).ipynb https://opencv-python-tutroals.readthedocs.io/en/latest/py_tutorials/py_imgproc/py_watershed/py_watershed.html Tip Kaggle is good platform that worths checking, you can find good practices there: https://www.kaggle.com/ I also recommend you to explore GitHub!
docs.title: Assignment 2

docs.title: UPDATE 10 March 2019

docs.text: Assigned: 10 March 2019 This is probably your last assignment before your actual (thesis) project. Do not loose your motivation even if it takes too long time to finish It will not be so easy in the first place but it will get easier! → Select your deep learning library ( list ). Be sure that you can play with simple examples like MNIST , Fashion-MNIST , and CIFAR with different CNN architectures (i.e. Alexnet, Resnet, VGG, etc.). For example, you can Display images Try different hyperparameters Try different losses Try different optimizers Use augmentation Add more layers Remove some layers If you haven't done yet, try to visualize (plot) train/validation/test losses. Ask Google and use the links on this webpage. The homework is about classification of texture images cropped from knee joint x rays. Cropped images are of size 64x64 (grayscale) They were cropped from the medial tibia from two different sites as shown below: A sample image and the cropped region (datasetA) A sample image and the cropped region (datasetB) Crops from right and left knee We have two different datasets (from OAI ) Download datasetA Download datasetB Warning Do not share/distribute the data! Name of the file is {id}.py . ID corresponds to subject identity. Each file is a numpy array. Each array has the following items: [ patches , id ] and patches is a dictionary such that there are two images (one from Right knee the other is from Left knee belonging to the same id ). You can use the following code snippet to read the file in python: import numpy as np from PIL import Image import matplotlib.pyplot as plt #read a file patches , p_id = np . load ( fname ) #get right image right_image = Image . fromarray ( patches [ 'R' ] . astype ( 'uint8' ), 'L' ) #left image left_image = Image . fromarray ( patches [ 'L' ] . astype ( 'uint8' ), 'L' ) #display them fig , ax = plt . subplots ( 1 , 2 ) ax [ 0 ] . imshow ( right_image ) ax [ 1 ] . imshow ( left_image ) plt . show () Each image is graded with a KL score (although you are supposed to be familiar with this (i.e. OA related material on the webpage ), if you are not familiar read below for a short introduction.) KL grading (click to expand) #from https://radiopaedia.org/articles/kellgren-and-lawrence-system-for-classification-of-osteoarthritis-of-knee The Kellgren and Lawrence (KL) system is a common method of classifying the severity of knee osteoarthritis (OA) using five grades 1. This classification was proposed by Kellgren et al. in 1957 2 and later accepted by WHO in 1961. In applying the system, the prevalence of chronic knee pain in a postal survey of 2000 Swedes aged 35-54 was 15%1. Of these respondents, 1% showed radiographic knee OA, based on bilateral weight bearing plain films1. Classification grade 0: no radiographic features of OA are present grade 1: doubtful joint space narrowing (JSN) and possible osteophytic lipping grade 2: definite osteophytes and possible JSN on anteroposterior weight-bearing radiograph grade 3: multiple osteophytes, definite JSN, sclerosis, possible bony deformity grade 4: large osteophytes, marked JSN, severe sclerosis and definite bony deformity The grades are stored in this following file baseline.csv . It is a table that shows different measures and outcomes for each id . Details about image assessment can be found here . Use pandas to read that ( .csv ) file and check the following colums for KL grading: 'ID' : subject ID 'V00XRKL' : grade 'SIDE' : side ( 1 : right , 2 : left ) There are 5 different grades: 0,1,2,3,4. Use following labels for multi-class classification Class 1: Grade0 , Class 2: Grade1 Class 3: Grade2 Class 4: Grade3 Class 5: Grade4 For binary classification, you can combine grades<2 and grades>1 : Class 1: Grade0, Grade1 Class 2: Grade2, Grade3, Grade4 If you are not familiar with pandas library read from here , here , here , here , here , or Google it! Things to do Now your task is to classify images using CNN. You are free to choose your architecture(s) State-of-the-art architectures You can also design your own architecture (strongly recommended) Test both binary classification and multi-class classification. Train and test datasetA and datasetB independently Use both R and L images but keep the two sides from the same id in the same fold ( train , test , validation ). For this, use pandas dataframes together with GroupKFold splitting from scikit-learn . Use 5-fold cross-validation ROC AUC score for evaluation Train on datasetA and test on datasetB For evaluation of binary classification, use both ROC and precision-recall curves and AUC and F1 score. Read : https://machinelearningmastery.com/roc-curves-and-precision-recall-curves-for-classification-in-python/ Train on datasetB and test on datasetA For evaluation of binary classification, use both ROC and precision-recall curves and AUC and F1 score. Send me only the curves (ROC and Precision-Recall) and numbers (AUC, F1) For GPU you can use the CSC cluster: https://research.csc.fi/taito-gpu Note (click to expand) I did not use this service before, therefore, I don't know the details please check from the web page. I heard that it might be tricky to configure this! Tip There are other cloud based services available for free: http://cs231n.github.io/gce-tutorial/ (limited time free) https://towardsdatascience.com/training-machine-learning-models-online-for-free-gpu-tpu-enabled-5def6a5c1ce3 https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1gJAAN3UI9005ecVmxPun5ZLCGu4YBtLo

docs.text: 1. Blame Texture Descriptors? # Fair comparison of deep learning and hand crafted features for OA detection: Be Fair Use exact same ROI for both. Same data augmentations. Same classifiers. Compare Winner? Are we looking at the right location? Texture ROI vs Full Joint Most informative region? 2. Do radiologist ever look at texture? # 3. Transform Radiographs to another image domain (MRI or another modality) # Conditional GANs Can we use GANs to generate new images that would contain more information about OA and then use AI methods for evaluation. 4. Landmark detection # Landmark Localization CNNs 5. Knee joint segmentation using deep neural networks # Partition knee radiographs into femur and tibia regions CNNs Fully CNNs U-Net 6. Registration # Warping input image onto a target image Deformable object registration Template matching Could be used also for: segmentation purposes landmark localization

docs.text: Setting up an environment # The operating system # Install Ubuntu: https://tutorials.ubuntu.com/tutorial/tutorial-install-ubuntu-desktop#0 Learn and Create a Virtual Environment # Install Anaconda & Python (3) https://conda.io/docs/user-guide/getting-started.html Install Python packages # Use virtual environment and conda to install scientific computing libraries. conda install numpy conda install scipy conda install matplotlib Learn numpy http://www.numpy.org/ Learn scipy https://www.scipy.org Install Machine and Deep Learning packages. # Install Scikit-learn https://scikit-learn.org/stable/ Select one of the deep learning library: - Pytorch - Tensorflow - Keras (Tensorflow) - Fast.ai ( https://www.fast.ai/ ) Python IDE # I recommend PyCharm

docs.text: Landmark Detection Ghesu, Florin C., Bogdan Georgescu, Tommaso Mansi, Dominik Neumann, Joachim Hornegger, and Dorin Comaniciu. "An artificial agent for anatomical landmark detection in medical images." In International Conference on Medical Image Computing and Computer-Assisted Intervention, pp. 229-237. Springer, Cham, 2016. Lai, Hanjiang, Shengtao Xiao, Yan Pan, Zhen Cui, Jiashi Feng, Chunyan Xu, Jian Yin, and Shuicheng Yan. "Deep recurrent regression for facial landmark detection." IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology 28, no. 5 (2018): 1144-1157. Bier, Bastian, Mathias Unberath, Jan-Nico Zaech, Javad Fotouhi, Mehran Armand, Greg Osgood, Nassir Navab, and Andreas Maier. "X-ray-transform invariant anatomical landmark detection for pelvic trauma surgery." In International Conference on Medical Image Computing and Computer-Assisted Intervention, pp. 55-63. Springer, Cham, 2018. Alansary, Amir, Ozan Oktay, Yuanwei Li, Loic Le Folgoc, Benjamin Hou, Ghislain Vaillant, Konstantinos Kamnitsas et al. "Evaluating Reinforcement Learning Agents for Anatomical Landmark Detection." Medical image analysis (2019). Xu, Zhoubing, Yuankai Huo, JinHyeong Park, Bennett Landman, Andy Milkowski, Sasa Grbic, and Shaohua Zhou. "Less is More: Simultaneous View Classification and Landmark Detection for Abdominal Ultrasound Images." In International Conference on Medical Image Computing and Computer-Assisted Intervention, pp. 711-719. Springer, Cham, 2018. Sofka, Michal, Fausto Milletari, Jimmy Jia, and Alex Rothberg. "Fully convolutional regression network for accurate detection of measurement points." Deep Learning in Medical Image Analysis and Multimodal Learning for Clinical Decision Support (2017): 258-266. Noothout, Julia MH, Bob D. de Vos, Jelmer M. Wolterink, Tim Leiner, and Ivana Išgum. "CNN-based Landmark Detection in Cardiac CTA Scans." arXiv preprint arXiv:1804.04963 (2018). Davison, Adrian K., Claudia Lindner, Daniel C. Perry, Weisang Luo, and Timothy F. Cootes. "Landmark Localisation in Radiographs Using Weighted Heatmap Displacement Voting." In International Workshop on Computational Methods and Clinical Applications in Musculoskeletal Imaging, pp. 73-85. Springer, Cham, 2018. Wang, Zi-Rui, Bao-Cai Yin, Jun Du, Cong Liu, Xiaodong Tao, and Guoping Hu. "Fast and Robust Detection of Anatomical Landmarks Using Cascaded 3D Convolutional Networks Guided by Linear Square Regression." In Chinese Conference on Biometric Recognition, pp. 599-608. Springer, Cham, 2018. Mader, Alexander Oliver, Cristian Lorenz, Martin Bergtholdt, Jens von Berg, Hauke Schramm, Jan Modersitzki, and Carsten Meyer. "Detection and localization of landmarks in the lower extremities using an automatically learned conditional random field." Graphs in Biomedical Image Analysis, Computational Anatomy and Imaging Genetics (2017): 64-75. Zhang, Jun, Mingxia Liu, and Dinggang Shen. "Detecting anatomical landmarks from limited medical imaging data using two-stage task-oriented deep neural networks." IEEE Transactions on Image Processing 26, no. 10 (2017): 4753-4764. Mader, Alexander Oliver, Cristian Lorenz, Martin Bergtholdt, Jens von Berg, Hauke Schramm, Jan Modersitzki, and Carsten Meyer. "Detection and localization of spatially correlated point landmarks in medical images using an automatically learned conditional random field." Computer Vision and Image Understanding 176 (2018): 45-53. Dong, Xuanyi, Yan Yan, Wanli Ouyang, and Yi Yang. "Style aggregated network for facial landmark detection." In Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition, pp. 379-388. 2018. Ranjan, Rajeev, Vishal M. Patel, and Rama Chellappa. "Hyperface: A deep multi-task learning framework for face detection, landmark localization, pose estimation, and gender recognition." IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence 41, no. 1 (2019): 121-135. Di, Xing, Vishwanath A. Sindagi, and Vishal M. Patel. "Gp-gan: Gender preserving gan for synthesizing faces from landmarks." In 2018 24 th International Conference on Pattern Recognition (ICPR), pp. 1079-1084. IEEE, 2018.

docs.text: State of the art : # U-Nets https://lmb.informatik.uni-freiburg.de/people/ronneber/u-net/ Fully convolutional networks (and variants) https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~jonlong/long_shelhamer_fcn.pdf Mask R-CNN http://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_ICCV_2017/papers/He_Mask_R-CNN_ICCV_2017_paper.pdf DeepLab https://github.com/tensorflow/models/blob/master/research/deeplab/README.md Good to know: # Semantic Segmentation vs. Instance Segmentation (Google it!) Datasets: # Here are the links for some public dataset. But there are many other datasets that can be used for testing your segmentation method. A big one: http://cocodataset.org/#home https://lear.inrialpes.fr/people/marszalek/data/ig02/ http://www.ntu.edu.sg/home/ASJFCai/Benchmark_Website/benchmark_index.html http://cs-chan.com/downloads_skin_dataset.html https://www.kaggle.com/c/data-science-bowl-2018/data https://www.kaggle.com/kmader/finding-lungs-in-ct-data Useful Links: # https://github.com/ZijunDeng/pytorch-semantic-segmentation http://lear.inrialpes.fr/people/klaeser/software For annotation: https://github.com/CSAILVision/LabelMeAnnotationTool
